content.description: This route is 1/4 mile from trailhead on the left (east side of the canyon), afternoon sun. Follow trail to amazing striped wall with finger/pillar leaning against it. This route faces South, right facing corner. Wide looking filled with a sandy loose pillar. Look for stream beds and stay off the soil crust. Ascend the weakness in the steps to arrive at the base.
content.protection: Finger size to #4.5 camalot. Can't place much though.

content.description: Route climb the spitter finger crack up the prow facing the canyon floor. Fingers to an easy OW. Great rock. Anchor needs to be replaced, it's really old.
content.protection: Many finger size pieces from .3 camalot to hands. #4 could be used at the top.
content.location: 1/4-1/2 mile from the trail head on the left. Find the dark pillar laying on the prow next to the large striped wall. Can be seen for the parking lot. Find stream beds and stay off of the soil crust when hiking out of the canyon. Some 4th class shelves to get to the base.

climbs.name: The Guides' Crack
climbs.fa: Nate Sydnor and Ed Oak (5.10 C1) - FFA Herb Crimp and Nate Sydnor

content.description: Any guide who is a climber and who has worked in this canyon has surely looked at this crack. The rock is actually quite good, and the climbing is varied and engaging. The thin start is likely the technical crux, but some steep thin hands jamming in the zig-zag crack up high offers a stimulating finish. Expect a little sugary rock, but overall this route is safe, with good protection, and better than I had expected.
content.protection: Doubles from less-than-tips to #3 Camalot, and a single #4
content.location: Prominent crack directly up the prow that stands above the south end of the arch. In order to approach, it is recommended to take the route to the alternate rappel and hike out to the top of the turret with a static line. Wrap the whole sugary summit as an anchor, then take the alternate rappel in and climb out.
